title: Year in Review (A Special Report)  ---  What Was News:  The big stories of 2022
text:
See an expanded version of this timeline with links to the original WSJ articles at wsj.com/yearinreview

Jan. 3: Holmes Is Convicted

Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes is found guilty of defrauding investors in the blood-testing company and will be sentenced to more than 11 years in prison

Jan. 12: Inflation Accelerates

Inflation reached 7% in 2021, Labor Department figures show, the fastest pace in nearly four decades

Jan. 18: Game Buy

Microsoft agrees to acquire videogame giant Activision Blizzard for about $75 billion, though the FTC will move to block the deal

Jan. 30: Living With Covid

The Omicron variant spreads so quickly and generally causes such a mild form of illness among vaccinated people that countries are forgoing restrictive steps used earlier in the pandemic

Feb. 7: Boxes at Mar-a-Lago

The National Archives says it retrieved 15 boxes of documents from Donald Trump's Florida residence

Feb. 11: Skater's Fall

Russia's gold medal in team figure skating at the Olympics is in doubt as officials confirm the team's 15-year-old star, Kamila Valieva, tested positive for a banned substance in December

Feb. 17: Baby Formula Recall

Abbott Laboratories recalls three types of formula made at a plant in Michigan, compounding supply-chain problems and helping to cause months of shortages

Feb. 24: Russia Invades Ukraine

Russian missiles and airstrikes hit Ukraine's capital, Kyiv, and more than a dozen other cities

Feb. 24: Swift Sanctions

The U.S. and its allies impose stiff sanctions on Russia

March 1: Targeting Civilian Areas

Russian forces, frustrated in plans for a quick victory in Ukraine, shift to a strategy of pummeling civilian areas

March 2: Oil Prices Surge

U.S. oil prices close above $110 a barrel for the first time since 2011 as the war in Ukraine starts to scramble the world's oil flows

March 3: Opioid Settlement

Sackler family members who own Purdue Pharma agree to pay up to $6 billion to settle lawsuits accusing them of helping fuel the opioid crisis

March 8: Arms for Ukraine

Russia's invasion of Ukraine has set off one of the largest and fastest arms transfers in history as the U.S. and its NATO allies rush to supply Ukraine's military

March 16: Fed Begins Raising Rates

Federal Reserve officials vote to lift interest rates to slow inflation and pencil in six more increases by year's end, the most aggressive pace in more than 15 years

March 16: Pullback From Russia

Western companies are pausing or ending operations in Russia, marking the end of an era after three decades of expansion there

March 25: Pullback by Russia

Russia says it is shifting the focus of its invasion of Ukraine to the country's east, ending its attempt to capture the capital, Kyiv, after a month of heavy losses

March 27: Oscars Drama

Will Smith strikes Chris Rock onstage at the Oscars shortly before winning the best actor award; the Motion Picture Academy will later ban him from attending Oscars ceremonies for 10 years

March 31: Markets in Turmoil

Amid war and inflation, stocks post their worst quarterly performance in two years as March comes to a close, and other markets have recorded some of the most extreme moves on record

April 3: Reports of Russian Atrocities

Ukrainian officials and independent rights watchdogs say they are uncovering evidence of war crimes in several regions that were occupied by Russian troops until their recent withdrawal

April 7: Supply-Chain Strains Grow

Manufacturers are struggling to keep some of their China operations going as Covid-19 lockdowns choke off supplies and clog up truck routes and ports

April 14: Ukraine Sinks the Moskva

The flagship of Russia's Black Sea Fleet sinks after what the Ukrainian military says was a missile strike on the vessel

April 19: Ads on Netflix?

After a rare quarterly loss of subscribers, Netflix says it may offer a lower-priced, ad-supported plan

April 22: Global Growth Ebbs

Economic growth is slowing in large parts of the globe due to Russia's war in Ukraine, Covid lockdowns in China and high inflation

April 25: Musk Has Twitter Deal

Twitter accepts a bid from Elon Musk to buy it for $44 billion

May 13: Judges' Finances

A new law requires federal judges to make more timely disclosures of their financial holdings and potential conflicts of interest; the bill was prompted by a WSJ investigation

May 14: Shooting in Buffalo

A gunman kills 10 people in a supermarket in Buffalo, N.Y., in a possible hate crime; most of those shot were Black

May 24: Texas School Shooter Kills 21

An 18-year-old man kills 19 students and two adults in an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas

June 9: Jan. 6 Committee Goes Public

In its first public hearing, the House panel investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol lays out an overview of its case against Donald Trump

June 15: Fed Goes Big

The Fed raises rates by 0.75 percentage point, its largest increase since 1994, stepping up efforts to slow inflation

June 16: Mortgage Rates Surge

U.S. mortgage rates had their biggest weekly increase since 1987, Freddie Mac says, and now stand at 5.78%, up from 3.11% near the end of last year

June 18: Crypto Party Is Over

Since bitcoin peaked in late 2021, about $2 trillion of cryptocurrency value has been erased, and an industry built on swagger and optimism is seeing losses and layoffs mount

June 21: Air Travel Chaos

Delays, cancellations, long lines and lost baggage are plaguing air travel worldwide, as airlines and airports struggle with soaring summer demand and staff shortfalls

June 24: Roe v. Wade Falls

The Supreme Court eliminates the constitutional right to an abortion, leaving the question of abortion's legality to the states

June 30: A New Justice

Ketanji Brown Jacksonis sworn in as the first Black female justice in the Supreme Court's history

July 12: Cosmic View

The first set of full-color images from the James Webb Space Telescope shows stellar nurseries and distant galaxies in exquisite detail

July 13: Inflation Hits 40-Year High

U.S. consumer inflation accelerated to 9.1% in June, the Commerce Department says

July 22: Ukraine Grain Deal

Russia and Ukraine agree to resume exports of millions of tons of Ukrainian grain via the Black Sea for the first time since the Russian invasion to prevent a global food crisis

July 28: Chips Bill Passes

The House sends to President Biden a $280 billion bill aimed at boosting the U.S. semiconductor industry in an effort to counter China

July 31: Drone Strike Kills al Qaeda Leader

A U.S. drone strike in Afghanistan kills Ayman al-Zawahiri, a strategist behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks

Aug. 2: Kansas Votes for Abortion Rights

Kansas voters reject a proposed state constitutional amendment that would have ended protections for abortion

Aug. 8: FBI Searches Trump Property

FBI agents search former President Trump's Mar-a-Lago home in Florida as part of a probe into his handling of sensitive documents

Aug. 16: A Win for Biden's Agenda

President Biden signs into law sweeping legislation to lower prescription drug prices, boost renewable energy and impose new taxes on large corporations

Aug. 18: Streaming Tops Cable

Streaming captured a greater share of U.S. viewing time than cable TV for the first time in July, new Nielsen data shows

Aug. 24: Student-Loan Break

The Biden administration says it will forgive up to $20,000 per borrower in federal student-loan debt, but the order will be put on hold by a legal challenge

Aug. 29: Floods in Pakistan

Widespread flooding from heavy monsoon rains has affected millions of people in Pakistan and killed more than 1,000 and crippled the nation's economy

Sept. 1: Learning Loss

The Education Department's first look at test-score trends since the pandemic began shows the worst drop in decades in math and reading scores for fourth-graders

Sept. 8: Queen Elizabeth II Dies

Britain's longest-serving monarch dies at 96 after seven decades on the throne; her son Charles becomes king

Sept. 10: Ukraine Offensive Makes Big Gains

Ukrainian troops push deep into Russian-held territory in the northeast of the country

Sept. 17: Protests in Iran

Protests erupt in Iran over a woman's death after a dress-code arrest, and will grow into a broader movement seeking an end to the country's system of Islamic governance

Sept. 28: Hurricane Batters Florida

Hurricane Ian makes landfall in Florida as one of the strongest storms on record to hit the U.S.

Sept. 30: Russia Stakes Claims

Russia announces the annexation of four regions of Ukraine it doesn't fully control as Ukrainian offensives continue to gain ground

Sept. 30: Stock Slump Deepens

U.S. stocks log their third straight quarterly decline; all three major indexes are down at least 21% for the year, their worst first nine months since 2002

Oct. 6: Biden to Issue Marijuana Pardons

President Biden says he will pardon thousands of people convicted of simple marijuana possession under federal law

Oct. 8: Crimea Bridge Blast

An explosion severely damages the bridge connecting Russia's mainland to the Crimean Peninsula, a crucial supply line to Russian troops in southern Ukraine

Oct. 10: Destroying Infrastructure

Russia unleashes a heavy barrage of missile strikes on Ukraine, in what will become a sustained campaign targeting the country's electric grid and other civilian infrastructure

Oct. 12: Jury Orders Alex Jones to Pay

Infowars host Alex Jones is ordered by a jury to pay $965 million in damages for repeatedly calling the 2012 Sandy Hook School massacre a hoax; a judge will add $473 million in punitive damages

Oct. 23: Tighter Grip in China
